comment: Thanks 🤍❤️
wow, i forgot these lectures was taped just months after the mortgage crisis

20:30 Ao/k is the total lifespan of all radioactive material combined instead of total number of particles. Where lifespan of a particle is defined as the time it takes to decay after t=0.  For a non-radioactive element k=0 which means total lifespan of non-radioactive material is infinity.

L'Hopital's Rule and rates of growth.  [00:00](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KhwQKE_tld0&t=0) L'Hopital's Rule and rates of growth were discussed in class.  [07:18](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KhwQKE_tld0&t=438) Understanding the convergence and divergence of integrals as x goes to infinity.  [13:53](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KhwQKE_tld0&t=833) Understanding the limit of a function when k is positive  [19:57](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KhwQKE_tld0&t=1197) Infinitesimal is easier than finite numbers  [25:02](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KhwQKE_tld0&t=1502) Fat tails in financial mathematics are a serious concern.  [30:28](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KhwQKE_tld0&t=1828) The integral from 1 to infinity / x^p diverges if p <= 1 and converges if p > 1.  [37:08](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KhwQKE_tld0&t=2228) Using the limit comparison method, we can easily decide whether an integral is finite or infinite.  [43:22](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KhwQKE_tld0&t=2602) Comparison of integrals shows convergence  ---------------------------------  Detailed Summary for [Lec 36 | MIT 18.01 Single Variable Calculus, Fall 2007](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KhwQKE_tld0) by [Merlin](https://merlin.foyer.work/)  [00:00](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KhwQKE_tld0&t=0) L'Hopital's Rule and rates of growth were discussed in class. - L'Hopital's Rule has three hypotheses and a single conclusion. - The comparison of functions can be expressed through the notation 'f is a lot less than g.' - Rates of decay are discussed as the inverse of rates of growth. - Improper integrals will be discussed in the next class.  [07:18](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KhwQKE_tld0&t=438) Understanding the convergence and divergence of integrals as x goes to infinity. - The integral from a to infinity of f(x) dx is defined as the limit as n goes to infinity of the ordinary definite integral up to some fixed, finite level. - The integral converges if the limit exists, and diverges if not. - The convergence or divergence of the integral has a geometric analog, which should always be considered. - The first example is the integral from 0 to infinity of e^ - kx dx, which converges to 1/k.  [13:53](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KhwQKE_tld0&t=833) Understanding the limit of a function when k is positive - The limit only works when k is positive and the total area is finite. - When discussing limits, 'exists' means that it is a finite number. - In dealing with infinity, it is important to plug in infinity correctly. - The limit can be any number, not just a positive one. - The limit of a radioactive substance's decay in the limit is equal to the total number of particles. - Although T going to infinity is an idealization, it is still used in physics as it simplifies the problem.  [19:57](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KhwQKE_tld0&t=1197) Infinitesimal is easier than finite numbers - The algebraic formulas are harder to compute than the infinitesimal ones - Integral from minus infinity to infinity of e^-x^2 dx equals the square root of pi, which is important in probability  [25:02](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KhwQKE_tld0&t=1502) Fat tails in financial mathematics are a serious concern. - Fat tails refer to unlikely events that still happen sometimes. - Proper mathematical understanding is necessary to deal with fat tails.  [30:28](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KhwQKE_tld0&t=1828) The integral from 1 to infinity / x^p diverges if p <= 1 and converges if p > 1. - Limit comparison is useful when you don't yet know the number and can make a comparison to something whose convergence properties you already understand. - If a function, f, is similar to a function, asymptotically the same as a function, g, as x goes to infinity, then the integral starting at some point out to infinity of f(x) dx and the other one, converge and diverge at the same time. - The tilde symbol means that f(x) / g(x) tends to 1. - The integral from 0 to infinity dx / the square root of x^2 + 10 resembles the square root of x^2, which is just x.  [37:08](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KhwQKE_tld0&t=2228) Using the limit comparison method, we can easily decide whether an integral is finite or infinite. - Limit comparison method makes no difference whether the integral can be computed or not. - Comparison is made with similar integrals that are already known to be convergent or divergent. - The comparison is made at the end of the picture as x goes to infinity. - The method helps to avoid computing difficult integrals.  [43:22](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KhwQKE_tld0&t=2602) Comparison of integrals shows convergence - The integral from 0 to 1 of e^-x^2 is finite - The integral from 1 to infinity of 2e^-x dx is a convergent integral

pretty interesting to hear in min 25 about "fat tails in finance and the morgage scandal". This was recorded in Fall 2007, and 15 years later we're still feeling the effects of the 2008 economic crisis.

Props to Saurav Bastola, https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC7hkeE-LRyzietNCecWnHLg for the listed topics. I think it is kinda obvious. For x=c, f(c) and g(c) both will yield approximately the same value (f/g being 1), hence, exhibiting same characteristics. Still, I would love to know your thought process. Correct me if I am wrong somewhere.
@sindhu8881 As x approaches infinity, if f(x)/g(x) approaches some other non-zero constant, say 500, can we still be certain that f and g either both converge or both diverge?

@malexmartinez4007  In limit comparison method, g(x) is derived out of f(x) (and vice versa) so that for any constant c, f(c) ≈ g(c). If f(x)/g(x) = c, then f(x) ≈ c*g(x). The integral would then approx differ by the factor of c but they both would still converge or diverge as x approaches infinity.
@sindhu8881  Thank you very much for clarifying.
